episodes.title: Episode 2: Her Mother, Her Grandmother, Her Truth — Remembering Elsie Bell
episodes.description:
In Episode 2 of Black Jonestown, Leslie Wagner Wilson sits down with Nancy Shaw — a woman whose family was forever changed by the promises and deceptions of Jim Jones.

Nancy opens her heart about losing her mother, who died believing Jones would heal her, and her grandmother, who perished in Jonestown. Through honesty, pain, and clarity, she brings forward a story few have ever heard directly from those who lived it.

This conversation is raw, intimate, and deeply human.
It speaks to faith, manipulation, grief, and the resilience it takes to reclaim your narrative after unimaginable loss.

Following the interview, we honor the life of Elsie Bell, remembering her not just as a victim of Jonestown, but as a woman whose life, hope, and humanity mattered.

Black Jonestown is dedicated to telling the stories behind the headlines — to show the family, not the spectacle.

If this episode moved you, please like, comment, and subscribe so we can continue sharing the voices and stories that history tried to silence.

episodes.title: Why “Drinking the Kool-Aid” Isn’t a Joke — Leslie Wagner Wilson Speaks
episodes.description:
Survivor. Mother. Advocate. Truth-teller.

In this powerful TikTok message, Leslie Wagner Wilson, one of the survivors of the Jonestown tragedy, explains why the phrase “drinking the Kool-Aid” is deeply painful and harmful to those who lived through the event — and to the families whose loved ones never came home.

This clip is shared to bring understanding, context, and respect to a phrase that has been used casually for decades without acknowledging the real people behind it.

As we continue the mission of the Black Jonestown project — honoring the lives, the stories, and the humanity of those who were part of Peoples Temple — let this serve as a reminder:

Words matter. History matters. And so do the people who survived it.

episodes.title: Episode 2 Preview — Black Jonestown
episodes.description:
In the upcoming episode, we sit down with Nancy Shaw, a former child in Peoples Temple whose grandmother died in Jonestown. Nancy shares her story with real, raw, and emotional transparency as she reflects on the memories she’s carried for decades.

We also honor the lives of several Peoples Temple members who died in Jonestown. Their stories will be told through narration, shared pictures, and video—giving space to their truth, their humanity, and their legacy.

And for everyone who’s been reaching out… we hear you!!
Leslie Wagner Wilson will begin answering your questions in upcoming episodes.

If you have a question about Peoples Temple, Jonestown, or anything discussed so far, send it to:
📩 therealblackjonestown@gmail.com

Episode 2 drops Wednesday, December 3rd.
Thank you for supporting this work, honoring these lives, and helping ensure their stories are told with the care their legacy deserves.

#BlackJonestown

episodes.title: Black Jonestown Podcast Episode 1
episodes.description:
Episode 1 opens the Black Jonestown Podcast with two powerful voices who carry firsthand memories of Peoples Temple. Survivor Leslie Wagner Wilson shares her lived experience and the path that led her to become the executive producer of this series. We are also joined by Jack Colbert, who grew up inside Peoples Temple and offers a rare perspective from someone who witnessed the community from childhood.

Together, they reflect, remember, and speak openly about life before Jonestown and the moments that shaped everything. This conversation sets the foundation for the journey ahead.

Subscribe for more interviews, stories, and insights as we uncover the truth—through the people who lived it.

episodes.title: Black Jonestown Trailer
episodes.description:
They weren’t lost souls or blind followers!
They were mothers, fathers, children, and dreamers — people of faith, community, and purpose who believed in building a better world.

Black Jonestown is a cinematic tribute to the Black members of the People’s Temple — those who lived, those who died, and those who survived the tragedy in Jonestown, Guyana. For decades, their humanity has been overshadowed by headlines and myths. This story reclaims their truth.

Through powerful storytelling, archival imagery, and haunting narration, the Black Jonestown series reveals who they really were — not victims of madness, but believers in hope, equality, and belonging.

This is not about how they died.
It’s about how they lived — and why their voices still matter.

✨ The first episode premieres November 18, 2025!!

Subscribe, share, and remember — because their story deserves to be told.
